title: Coalition Formation Game in the Cross-Silo Federated Learning System
summaries: in the cross-silo FL framework that DOs are also MOs, propose __[1] a disjoint coalition formation algorithm__ which maximizes the global model satisfaction level, __[2] a fair cost sharing scheme__ to align individual utility with the coalition utility
systemModel: Problem
under __the IID assumption__, the model accuracy and the data size show a _concave down increasing trend_, while the _costs also increase_ as the coalition becomes larger
when the increase in model accuracy cannot offset the extra cooperation cost due to the large size of the grand coalition, __a small coalition would be preferred__
model maybe weaker but cost also lower, leading to a possible higher utility
Objectives
design a coalition formation game, where
__organizations are grouped into disjoint stable coalitions__ so that each small coalition's utility is no less than that of the grand coalition
__a fair cost sharing mechanism__ is designed to avoid free-riders by aligning members' individual utility with the coalition utility
Assumptions:
IID data distribution among organizations<ol>
no organizations are joining or leaving
organizations share an identical standard to reflect their satisfaction on the global model
Players & Notations
$O$: the set of $N$ organizations
$\mathcal{B}$: all sets of partitions of $O$
$\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{B}$: a partition
$S \in \mathcal{P}$: a coalition
$l(S)=\theta \log(1 + \lambda \cdot q(S))$: the satisfaction level on the model generated by a coalition $S$
$q(S)$: the total amount of training data in $S$
$c(S)=c_{srv}(S) + c_{org}(S)$: cost in each global aggregation
$c_{srv}(S)$: the computation and communication cost caused by the _coalition server_, growing quadratically with the size of coalition

$c_{org}(S)$: from all _coalition members_, the computation cost which grows quadratically with the size of coalition (_this assumption reasonable?_), and communication cost which grows linearly with the size of the coalition
therefore, $c(S)=\alpha |S|^2 + \beta |S|$
$o_i$: an individual player
$d_i$: data size
$b_i$: budget
techniques: The Centralized Approach

$\begin{array}{ll} \underset{\mathcal{P}}{\operatorname{maximize}} & \frac{\sum_{S\in \mathcal{P}} |S| \cdot l(S)}{N} \quad \textit{(average model satisfaction level)} \\  \text {subject to } & c(S)\leq |S| \cdot b_S, \quad \forall S\in \mathcal{P}, \quad \textit{(budget constraint)}\\ \textit{where } b_S=\min_{o_i \in S}b_i \end{array}$
Solving this problem is __NP-complete__, due to [1] the number possible coalitions grows exponentially with $N$, and [2] $l(S), c(S)$ depend on the optimization parameter $\mathcal{P}$
The Distributed Approach
Concepts:
Orders(criteria)<ol>
_coalition value orders_ compare the value of two partitions $\mathcal{W}=\{S_1,...,S_l\}$ and $\mathcal{P}\{S_1',...,S_k'\}$
$\mathcal{W} \triangleright \mathcal{P}$ implies $\sum_{i=1}^l u(S_i) > \sum_{j=1}^k u(S_j')$
_individual value orders_ compare individual payoff
$\mathcal{W} \triangleright \mathcal{P}$ implies $\{x_i \geq x_i', \forall o_i \in \mathcal{W}, \mathcal{P}\}$
Stability
in __$\mathbb{D}_{hp}$-stable partition__, no coalitions have an incentive to pursue coalition formation through _merge-and-split_
Based on $\mathbb{D}_{hp}$-stable partition, an __adaptive coalition formation algorithm__ is proposed (covered in the article)
in __$\mathbb{D}_{c}$-stable partition__, no coalitions have an incentive to pursue coalition formation through _any operation_
although $\mathbb{D}_{c}$-stable partition is the unique outcome that maximizes the social welfare, such a partition only exists under certain conditions (covered in the article)
if such conditions meet, the proposed algorithm converges to this optimal $\mathbb{D}_{c}$-stable partition; otherwise, it converges to $\mathbb{D}_{hp}$-stable partition
Fair Cost Sharing

as seen before, __the total coalition cost only depends on the size of the coalition__ (the costs among organizations are identical). therefore, it is reasonable to distribute the total cost based on contribution: $c(S)a_i/\sum_{o_j \in S} a_j$
$a_i=d_i$: when contribution is measured as the size of trained data
$a_i=\theta \log(1+\lambda d_i)$: when contribution is measured as local model accuracy
$a_i=\phi_i$: when contribution is measured with the Shapley Value
